div1.p: Edward McPherson's sister, Kate Scott, mentions her preference for Democratic candidates, complains of slow workmen, and shares news of friends and family. She also notes that Edward's attention to politics is diverting his attentions away from his friends and family.

I recieved a paper from you this eve which informs me of your where abouts. I had not heard of your return to G--. since your trip to N York. We all regretted very much you could not make us a visit hope you will very soon. You are so absorbed in politics you seem not to have time for your friends. this ought-- not to be, there are so few of us left and we ought to see more of each other. I had a long letter from sister from Altona but do not know where she is now. I wanted her to come here but, I dont know whether she will or not we are not fixed yet in our back building but -- could get- along. the workmen here do try one's patience too much. I hardly know what to do
sometimes. I get out of humour with them might all have been done long since, by the paper to night you are highly complimented and will likely be the Candidate again. I cannot think you are on the right side. I am strong for Bell and Everett have just been reading Crittendon's speech which pleases me mightily. We had a visit-- Saturday from -- Professor Reynolds your old Teacher. he is looking remarkably well and in fine spirits, he thinks I have changed very little, he tells me he has quite a family 8 children, he called in yesterday and for sometime with Dr in the Office and talked many things, he seems to be very much pleased with your course, he says there three young men he feels very proud Robert Clarkson, William Paxton and you. I was so sorry to hear of Miss Maria McClellen's death, she will be such a loss her sister and brothers. I sometimes think going over to G--. for a day or two this fall can't know yet. I still have a yearning after place. I see you have the gas in operation
You must feel quite grand.

How long will you be in G--. now. You are kind of passage. I now know where to find you. I enclose this note you wished me to sign. the glasses arrived safely and are and look very well. The children are very well. Lillie and Mae are tired of vacation and wish school would commence. The William's have not got home yet. Mary Emma and her Father went to the Springs, Nannie Findley went with them and Cousin Nancy went to Jinnie's, all be home soon. It is late and I will to stop. Write soon again. Love to all for
